Situation1: They occasionally participate in family traditions during holidays and gatherings.
Expectation2: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation2: The build is stalled because no one can proceed until their core module is complete
Story: I stared at my laptop, code blurring as my stepmother’s voice echoed from the kitchen. “Dinner’s almost ready! Don’t forget, you’re carving the turkey this year.” It was Thanksgiving, and my family expected me to join in, to honor the traditions that made us feel like a real family, even if I sometimes felt like an outsider. But my phone buzzed with urgent Slack messages from my team. The project deadline loomed, and the entire build was stalled—no one could move forward until I finished the core module. My manager’s last message was clear: “We need your update tonight.” I could hear laughter and clinking dishes from the dining room, the warmth of belonging just out of reach. My heart pounded as I weighed the expectations—be the reliable engineer my team depended on, or the devoted step-child my family wanted me to be. I closed my eyes, feeling the pressure of both worlds, knowing I couldn’t fully satisfy either.
